tags: THIS MAKES ZERO SENSE BUT ALSO SANSA WOULD
imagine theyre breaking into the red keep to kill cersei
summary:
Sansa: lets do ‘get help’
Arya: what?
Sansa: ‘get help’
Arya: no
Sansa: come on, you love it
Arya: I hate it
Sansa: it’s great....
body:
Sansa: lets do ‘get help’

Arya: what?

Sansa: ‘get help’

Arya: no

Sansa: come on, you love it

Arya: I hate it

Sansa: it’s great. It works everytime

Arya: it’s humiliating

Sansa: do you have a better plan?

Arya: no

Sansa: we’re doing it

Arya: we are not doing ‘get help’

*several minutes later*

Sansa, dragging Arya: Get help! Please! My sister is dying! Get help! Help her!

Sansa: *throws Arya at a few guards, knocking them over*

Sansa: classic!

Arya, getting up: I still hate it. It’s humiliating

Sansa: not for me, it’s not

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: Another reason to ship Sansan: Arya would be the worst/best sister in law to Sandor. In barbecue meetings, she'd ask Sansa "What...
body: Another reason to ship Sansan: Arya would be the worst/best sister in law to Sandor. In barbecue meetings, she’d ask Sansa “What did you even see in that guy?” then slap him in the butt and tell him to move over the grill because he can’t cook for shit. He would called her a brat and they would fight for the fork while Sansa rolls her eyes.

reblog.comment: Another reason to ship Sansan: Arya would be the worst/best sister in law to Sandor. He would called her a brat and they would fight for the fork while Sansa rolls her eyes.

blog.name: thatgirlnevershutsup
blog.title: The Return of the Queen
blog.description: such a classic girl

summary: for your first sentence meme - 'Sansa looked up at Cersei's head, impaled on a spike, and finally started to relax.'
question: for your first sentence meme - 'Sansa looked up at Cersei's head, impaled on a spike, and finally started to relax.'
answer:
Sansa looked up at Cersei’s head, impaled on a spike, and finally started to relax.

She had thought she would never return to King’s Landing, but she was Queen of the Seven Kingdoms now, and this was her place, and she had what Cersei never did — the love of the people, and her husband.

“Sansa, are you ready?”

She nodded as she took his arm, and let him lead her back into the Red Keep, back to the throne room where the court had gathered. Cersei Lannister was merely the first who would face justice — Sansa still had more to deliver, and her people were waiting for her to proceed.

She nodded as she took his arm, and let him lead her back into the Red Keep, back to the throne room where the court had gathered. Cersei Lannister was merely the first who would face justice — Sansa still had more to deliver, and her people were waiting for her to proceed.

Sansa looked up at Cersei’s head, impaled on a spike, and finally started to relax.

She had thought she would never return to King’s Landing, but she was Queen of the Seven Kingdoms now, and this was her place, and she had what Cersei never did — the love of the people, and her husband.

“Sansa, are you ready?”

She nodded as she took his arm, and let him lead her back into the Red Keep, back to the throne room where the court had gathered. Cersei Lannister was merely the first who would face justice — Sansa still had more to deliver, and her people were waiting for her to proceed.

blog.name: fedonciadale
blog.title: FedonCiadale
blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

summary: What plots in this post-book show canon, if any, do you think actually belong to a different character than shown? I.e. Sansa...
question: What plots in this post-book show canon, if any, do you think actually belong to a different character than shown? I.e. Sansa taking over Jeyne's marriage to Ramsay. Do you think any character on the show now is actually fulfilling the arc of a book character, or having their storyline merged with a book character?
answer:
Dear nonny,

that is a difficult question….

Obviously it depends quite a lot on what I think will happen in the books, so you have to take this with a huge grain of salt!

I think that the show actually is not that different from what the books will be. And certainly far less different than book purists claim. For example, I’m convinced that Sansa will end up North (as the girl in grey), and that she and Jon will reclaim Winterfell. I also believe that Stannis will indeed sacrifice his daughter for better weather in the books - it is his tragedy that he who believes that he is the chosen one will fail spectacularly.

I also believe that the Dorne storyline will be cut short, not as brutal as in the show, but Doran Martell has been set up as a schemer who will scheme himself to death. In the show they did botch the Dorne storyline but I guess in the end the result will be almost the same: Dornish without any Martell to rule them. Arianne and fAegon will go down in the books, so that by the time Da€nerys meets Jon she will think that the treasons are beyond her.

I also believe the Tyrion will end up as a councillor to Da€nerys maybe even her Hand, and I believe that Da€nerys will bend the Khals into submission as well.


Arya’s arc has been changed as well. She didn’t meet Lady Stoneheart in the show, but I guess we will see her and possibly Jaime when the Freys meet their fate. I also think that there will be some tension between Sansa and Arya when they meet again, because they have to work out their issues. I just hope it won’t be as bad as the Winterhell plot in season 7.

Also Cersei blowing up the sept will happen. I doubt that she’ll rule in her own right though, because the rules of succession GRRM has put up don’t allow for that in the books. I guess bookwise Tommen will be around longer.

So the main characters are set on the same path I think. It is minor characters who have been propped up (like Lyanna Mormont) or reduced (like Alys Karstark) or cut out entirely. So, there is plenty of merging there. The betrayal of the Umbers and Karstarks is a merging of Karstark and Dustins in the books I would say, while Lyanna Mormont possibly is just the representative of loyal Northern Lords (of which we have way more in the books). But I’m not sure this would count as merging, I would rather name it reducing to the bullet points, I guess.

Some people have said, that Jon’s arc is merged with fAegon’s from the book, but I am not sure about that. This interpretation is mainly born from Jon’s name being Aegon on the show and the fact that Jon and Da€nerys meet under circumstances that might set them up as enemies (and you know, they are ice and fire and can’t be enemies, while it is pretty clear, that Da€nerys will roast fAegon in the books).

I am not so sure about that, tbh. As I said above: They have brutally cut the Dorne storyline and I think fAegon is very much part of this and will go down with Dorne, maybe even before Da€nerys arrives or shortly afterwards. And as much as I dislike Aegon as a name for Jon, it is not unconceivable that this is his name. When he was born, the male heirs of Rhaegar were dead and how better claim his legitimacy than giving him the very name of the dynasty’s founder? I do think that people who claim Jon has taken over fAegon’s arc want to explain why Jon and Da€nerys have been set up for a Targbowl at least in part, and they explain the political differences with the lingering residues of fAegon’s storyline. I doubt that.

I think it is even likely that Jon will set out to get dragons, he wished for them in ASOS after all, and the circumstance of his first meeting with Da€nerys will also not be perfect. Turn it as you want, their political goals are different. Not unsurmountable different, but difficult, and by the end of season 7 they haven’t worked out a compromise, but a takeover so to say. Nothing in season 7 points towards Jon’s arc as fAegon influenced. The only thing that might be interpreted this way is that GRRM claimed that Jon and Da€nerys will “meet later” in the books - whatever that means.

So, imho, the meeting of Jon and Da€nerys in the books will be in quite similar circumstances, Jon desperately seeking an alliance, Da€nerys refusing it and Jon being ‘political Jon’.

To sum up: I think that the Sansa/fArya=Jeyne swap was a single occasion. I don’t think any of the other changes are that drastic. But this is only my take on what will happen in the books. Lots of what we have seen on screen is far less intricate than the books, but the major plot points are reached, even if some of the characters suffer from the reduction - Arya for example.

Thanks for the ask!

Nothing in season 7 points towards Jon’s arc as fAegon influenced. The only thing that might be interpreted this way is that GRRM claimed that Jon and Da€nerys will “meet later” in the books - whatever that means.

So, imho, the meeting of Jon and Da€nerys in the books will be in quite similar circumstances, Jon desperately seeking an alliance, Da€nerys refusing it and Jon being ‘political Jon’.

To sum up: I think that the Sansa/fArya=Jeyne swap was a single occasion. I don’t think any of the other changes are that drastic. But this is only my take on what will happen in the books. Lots of what we have seen on screen is far less intricate than the books, but the major plot points are reached, even if some of the characters suffer from the reduction - Arya for example.

Thanks for the ask!

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary:
Inktober Catch Up Part 2! Another process video, this time of this image.
These two are Sansa and Arya from my Staying Together...
body:
Inktober Catch Up Part 2! Another process video, this time of this image.

These two are Sansa and Arya from my Staying Together AU, where they have to work as small folk. Day 5 of the Inktober Prompts was “chicken”, so here’s Sansa feeding and distracting the chickens while Arya gets the eggs.

summary: This is a monster. An unfinished one. I originally started this as a cyberpunk ciri image with ciri, the bike and warehouse. I...
caption:
This is a monster. An unfinished one. I originally started this as a cyberpunk ciri image with ciri, the bike and warehouse. I then added the androids since I’ve had the figure for while and never used it. Then I started adding in more figures that I’ve for a total of twelve.
The problem I started having was beside taking forever to load, is that I can’t get it to render in Iray. I started this in late July, it was was mostly done by mid August. Either Daz shuts down or my laptop reboots when I try.
This was rendered in 3ds and the fact that it rendered at all is shocking. It seem 12 figures and props are the limit for now. The scene is saved and I try again at a latter date.

summary: a bit of style testing, featuring Our Lady of Stark I decided to move away from Sophie Turner’s likeness for this experiment and...
caption:
a bit of style testing, featuring Our Lady of Stark

I decided to move away from Sophie Turner’s likeness for this experiment and just draw Sansa as best as I could as I see her… still used references - mostly those dress up dolls character creator thingies, but that was more so for the cartoon-ish style I’m trying to emulate, b/c me drwing real people’s faces just doesn’t translate well into the style I’m trying, I always end up with semi-realism

problem is, the two of these took me like an hour, it’s so slow going it’s driving me nuts

blog.name: secretlyatargaryen
blog.title: Worms are crawling in and out of Rhaegar's ass
blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: Sansa being forced into marriage is an abuse of the feudal system and custom of arranged marriage, and I've talked about how...
body:
Sansa being forced into marriage is an abuse of the feudal system and custom of arranged marriage, and I’ve talked about how even though it’s an extreme situation, it’s a product of a system that allows this kind of thing to happen. It is easy to blame the Lannisters in this case and say this particular situation is abusive for Sansa (and it is) because in most cases her family would be the ones choosing a marriage for her and we can say that Ned and Cat would never force Sansa into a situation that was unsafe for her (although they betrothed her to Joffrey.)

But, what about situations where your family doesn’t care about your well-being? This system is inherently rigged against Tyrion because not only does Tyrion have specific trauma related to his disability that would make any arranged marriage humiliating and awful, not only does the system position Tyrion as too disabled for a high match and too high born for anyone else, but Tyrion’s father doesn’t care at all for his son’s personal safety, wants and needs. The specific situation Tywin puts Tyrion in is abusive because ordering someone to abuse someone else is itself a form of abuse of that person, but the system is specifically rigged to allow that kind of situation to happen. Which is one reason why Tyrion’s marriage to Tysha was such a huge social transgression. As a disabled person Tyrion having control over his own body is itself a transgression. And this is also a result of societal misogyny, because Tyrion’s disability makes him only half a man, and therefore closer to a woman, which in a patriarchal society is the worst thing you can be.

reblog.comment:

But, what about situations where your family doesn’t care about your well-being? This system is inherently rigged against Tyrion because not only does Tyrion have specific trauma related to his disability that would make any arranged marriage humiliating and awful, not only does the system position Tyrion as too disabled for a high match and too high born for anyone else, but Tyrion’s father doesn’t care at all for his son’s personal safety, wants and needs. The specific situation Tywin puts Tyrion in is abusive because ordering someone to abuse someone else is itself a form of abuse of that person, but the system is specifically rigged to allow that kind of situation to happen. Which is one reason why Tyrion’s marriage to Tysha was such a huge social transgression. As a disabled person Tyrion having control over his own body is itself a transgression. And this is also a result of societal misogyny, because Tyrion’s disability makes him only half a man, and therefore closer to a woman, which in a patriarchal society is the worst thing you can be.

It is easy to blame the Lannisters in this case and say this particular situation is abusive for Sansa (and it is) because in most cases her family would be the ones choosing a marriage for her and we can say that Ned and Cat would never force Sansa into a situation that was unsafe for her (although they betrothed her to Joffrey.)

But, what about situations where your family doesn’t care about your well-being? This system is inherently rigged against Tyrion because not only does Tyrion have specific trauma related to his disability that would make any arranged marriage humiliating and awful, not only does the system position Tyrion as too disabled for a high match and too high born for anyone else, but Tyrion’s father doesn’t care at all for his son’s personal safety, wants and needs. blog.name: girlysword
blog.title: Girlysword
blog.description: If you should ever think me smart, don't be fooled. I am better talking about things than doing them.

summary: Okay, there is no chance that Sansa is dying, but let's pretend that there is for a second. Sansa's death would be a HUGE deal....
body: Okay, there is no chance that Sansa is dying, but let’s pretend that there is for a second. Sansa’s death would be a HUGE deal. I’m talking Ned Stark execution, Red wedding, Sept of Baelor, kind of deal. GRRM is not the kind of writer to spend so much time on a character only to write a death where people are sad for a bit and then move on. Give me a theory where Sansa’s death completely shifts the paradigm of the show, and then I’ll consider it.

tags: i've gone so long without moaning about d&d and now i am and want to die again
summary: breath217 replied to your ask:’Sorry to bother but could you explain me a little bit of the fake arya...’ So you think Sansa...
body:
breath217 replied to your ask:’Sorry to bother but could you explain me a little bit of the fake arya…’

So you think Sansa will ride in with the vale in the books?

Yep, I do, with a direwolf stitched onto her dress, after she’s been declared to the Vale as Sansa Stark; and that support will save Jon’s ass in the book version of the Battle of the Bastards. The situation will be the same but the context different - and therefore the dynamic they seem to be wanting in the show of ‘Sansa is bitter because Jon is King when she provided the Vale’ will actually feel natural. Because Jon won’t have rescued her and protected her from anyone. She’ll be riding up to reclaim the north and discover her brother got there before her, and the glory she was expecting will be taken away from her and given to him.

Because, as always, GRRM thinks these scenarios through in a way D&D just seem utterly stupid with smh
